intro: Arceuthobium gambyi, commonly known as the Indian pine mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that primarily infests the roots of certain pine trees. It belongs to the Viscaraceae family and is characterized by its lack of chlorophyll, relying entirely on its host for nutrients. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers and berries that are dispersed by birds. Its life cycle involves a complex interaction with both the host tree and its seed-dispersing avian partners. Due to its specialized parasitic nature, it plays a unique role in the ecological dynamics of pine forest ecosystems.
